headline: The Republican Civil Rights Legacy
introduction: Before the Southern Strategy, the Republican Party had a century-long civil rights legacy. Understanding what they chose to abandon makes the strategic shift more significant.

civilRightsActVote.headline: The Civil Rights Act Vote (1964)
civilRightsActVote.description: Both parties split on the Civil Rights Act, but Republicans were MORE likely to vote yes than Democrats, especially in the Senate.
civilRightsActVote.note: Without Republican votes, the Civil Rights Act would not have passed. The split was regional, not purely partisan: Northern Democrats and most Republicans voted yes; Southern Democrats voted no.

legacyHighlights.description: Republicans led the fight to end slavery and passed the 13th, 14th, and 15th Amendments during Reconstruction.
legacyHighlights.significance: This was the party's founding identity.

legacyHighlights.description: Twenty-two Black Americans served in Congress during Reconstruction, all Republicans. Hiram Revels (MS) and Blanche Bruce (MS) served in the Senate.
legacyHighlights.significance: The GOP was the party of Black political representation.

legacyHighlights.description: President Eisenhower deployed the 101st Airborne to Little Rock, Arkansas to enforce school desegregation at Central High School.
legacyHighlights.significance: A Republican president used federal force to protect civil rights.

legacyHighlights.description: 82% of Republican senators voted for the Civil Rights Act (vs. 69% of Democrats). GOP votes were essential to overcoming the Southern Democratic filibuster.
legacyHighlights.significance: Republicans helped break the filibuster that Southern Democrats used to block civil rights.

moderatesFigures.name: Nelson Rockefeller
moderatesFigures.role: Governor of New York, Presidential Candidate
moderatesFigures.civilRightsRecord: Strong supporter of civil rights legislation, represented the party's moderate-to-liberal wing
moderatesFigures.whatHappened: Lost 1964 GOP nomination to Goldwater; the party chose the Southern Strategy path

moderatesFigures.name: Jacob Javits
moderatesFigures.civilRightsRecord: Co-sponsored civil rights legislation, champion of liberal Republican tradition
moderatesFigures.whatHappened: Lost 1980 primary to conservative challenger as party moved right

moderatesFigures.name: Edward Brooke
moderatesFigures.civilRightsRecord: First Black senator elected by popular vote since Reconstruction; moderate Republican
moderatesFigures.whatHappened: Lost 1978 reelection; represented a wing of the party that faded with the Southern Strategy

theChoice.headline: The Road Not Taken
theChoice.explanation: In 1964, Republicans faced a choice: the Rockefeller path (civil rights, Northern moderates) or the Goldwater path (Southern whites opposed to civil rights). They chose Goldwater. That choice shaped the next six decades.

goldwaterQuote.text: Extremism in the defense of liberty is no vice. Moderation in the pursuit of justice is no virtue.
goldwaterQuote.source: Barry Goldwater, 1964 Republican Convention acceptance speech
goldwaterQuote.context: This line was understood by both supporters and opponents as rejecting the moderate wing's approach to civil rights.

conclusion: The Southern Strategy wasn't inevitable. Republicans had spent a century building a civil rights legacy. Goldwater, Nixon, and Reagan made a strategic choice to pursue white Southern voters by opposing federal civil rights enforcement, against their own party's history.
